Expectation1: Respond to emails and messages within a reasonable time frame
Situation1: Leadership needs a prompt reply to confirm details for an external partner.
Expectation2: Write clean, maintainable, and efficient code
Situation2: A critical service is slowing under load and traces point to their recently merged functions
Story: My phone buzzes with a new email from leadership, subject line urgent, asking me to confirm details for an external partner meeting. I know they expect a prompt reply—anything less could hold up the project and reflect poorly on our team. At the same time, my IDE is open, and I’m staring at a block of code I wrote last week. The service is buckling under load, and the traces point directly to my recent changes. I can already hear the frustration in the ops channel. I know I need to focus, to dig in and refactor, to make the code clean and efficient before things get worse. But the unread messages keep piling up, and I can almost feel my colleagues’ impatience through the screen. My mind races, torn between the expectation to be a responsive teammate and the responsibility to fix my code. My hands hover over the keyboard, caught between drafting a quick reply and diving into the code, feeling the weight of both roles pressing in from either side.
